Let’s walk how this is done. Kubernetes version is 1.28 and the cluster is set up with EKS. First, name resolution from the Service’s FQDN to the ClusterIP is done by querying kube-dns (coredns) according to the nameserver setting in /etc/resolv.conf of each Pod.

item.title: Priority of K8s pods and preemption
item.description: When you specify the priorityClassName of a Pod, the value of the corresponding PriorityClass becomes the Priority of the Pod. apiVersion: scheduling.k8s.io/v1 kind: PriorityClass metadata: name: low-priority value: -10 globalDefault: false description: 'pods can be preempted' apiVersion: apps/v1 kind: Deployment spec: template: spec: priorityClassName: low-priority When a Pod is scheduled and its preemptionPolicy is the default PreemptLowerPriority, preempt other Pods with a lower priority to reserve requested resources. item.title: Pods evicted without waiting for terminationGracePeriodSeconds due to lack resources of Kubernetes nodes
item.description: If you specify only requests resources of memory or ephemeral-storage that includes emptyDir volume, pods can consume resources more than settings, and kubelet monitors following signals and may evict them to avoid running out of node resources. memory.available nodefs.available nodefs.inodesFree imagefs.available imagefs.inodesFree pid.available These thresholds can be set using evictionSoft and evictionHard in KubeletConfiguration, and if the soft value is reached, there is an eviction-max-pod-grace-period until it is evicted, but if the hard value is also reached, pods are immediately evicted.

item.title: Setting security groups for node instances in an EKS cluster created with CDK
item.description: securityGroup that can be passed when creating an aws_eks.Cluster is not associated with the node instances but with the control plane’s ENI. There’s defaultCapacity field in Cluster, so I attempted to add a SG through it, but nothing happened. When an EKS cluster is created, if the DefaultCapacityType is NODEGROUP, which is the default, it creates a managed node group, which consists of defaultCapacity nodes, where operations such as drains are managed by EKS.

item.title: Install Karpenter on an EKS cluster with CDK to auto-scale flexibility and quickly
item.description: Karpenter is an OSS that scales a Kubernetes cluster developed by AWS. Compared to Cluster Autoscaler, it can perform fast and flexible provisioning not through Auto Scaling Group. It supports only EKS so far, but it seems to have possibility to support other cloud providers. (PS: 2023-12-06) now available on AKS In this article, I install Karpenter on an EKS cluster with CDK, and confirm the cluster to be auto-scaled when the number of replicas is changed.
